p: The genomes of several invasive species have now been sequenced and assembled as well as annotated to differing extents. These include the tunicate Ciona intestinalis (Dehal et al. 2002), dengue mosquito vector Aedes aegypti (Nene et al. 2007), argentine ant Linepithema humile (Smith et al. 2011), fire ant Solenopsis invicta, (Wurm et al. 2011), diamondback moth Plutella xylostella (You et al. 2013), domestic cat Felis catus (Pontius et al. 2007) and mallard Anas platyrhynchos (Huang et al. 2013). Then, there are the genomes of model species that are also invasive, which include Drosophila species such as D. melanogaster and D. suzukii (Adams et al. 2000; Chiu et al. 2013), rats and mice (Waterston et al. 2002; Gibbs et al. 2004), and some weedy plants, such as the castor bean (Chan et al. 2010). Some of these species are useful for climatic studies, based on evidence for geographic variation in climate responses in species such as the drosophilids (Hoffmann et al. 2003) and C. intestinalis (Dybern 1965).
